facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1018 of 1963 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1018 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated February 21, 1962, of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petition No. 275 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated February 21, 1962, of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Petition No. 275 of 1961.

facts.text: K. Daphtary, Attorney-General, M. Adhikari, Advocate General, Madhya Pradesh, H. L. Khaskalam and I. N. Shroff argued for the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: K. Daphtary, Attorney-General, M. Adhikari, Advocate General, Madhya Pradesh, H. L. Khaskalam and I. N. Shroff, for the appellants.

facts.text: V. Gupte, Solicitor-General and J. B. Dadachanji argued for the respondents.

anchor.surface_text: V. Gupte, Solicitor-General and J. B. Dadachanji, for the respondents.

facts.text: N. Kacker and J. P. Goyal argued for the intervener.

anchor.surface_text: N. Kacker and J. P. Goyal, for the intervener.

facts.text: SARKAR, J. delivered a separate opinion.

anchor.surface_text: SARKAR, J. delivered a separate opinion.

facts.text: Notification under s. 4(1) issued on May 16, 1949, declaring lands in eleven villages including village Chhawani likely needed for erection of an iron and steel plant.

anchor.surface_text: On May 16, 1949, a notification was issued under s. 4(1) of the Act by which it was declared that lands in eleven villages including village Chhawani was likely to be needed for a public purpose, i.e., the erection of an iron and steel plant.

facts.text: Notifications under s. 6 issued with respect to villages notified under s. 4(1), including a number for village Chhawani.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that thereafter notifications were issued under s. 6 with respect to the villages notified in the notification under s. 4(1) and it is not in dispute that a number of such notifications under S. 6 were issued with respect to village Chhawani

facts.text: Some land in village Chhawani was acquired under previous s. 6 notifications, last acquisition in 1956.

anchor.surface_text: and some land in that village was acquired under those notifications, the last of such acquisitions being in the year 1956.

facts.text: On August 12, 1960, notification under s. 6 issued proposing to acquire 486-17 acres of land in village Chhawani.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter on August 12, 1960, another notification under s. 6 of the Act was issued by the appropriate government proposing to acquire 486-17 acres of land in village Chhawani

facts.text: The 1960 s.6 notification demarcated the area on a map kept in the office of the Collector of Durg for inspection.

anchor.surface_text: and the area which was proposed to be acquired was demarcated on a map kept in the office of the Collector of Durg for inspection.

facts.text: 1960 s.6 notification stated that provisions of s.5-A shall not apply.

anchor.surface_text: The notification also stated that the provisions of S. 5-A of the Act shall not apply thereto.

facts.text: Respondents, interested in some of the land notified, filed a writ petition in the High Court challenging the validity of the 1960 s.6 notification.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the respondents who are interested in some of the land notified filed a writ petition in the High Court challenging the validity of the notification under s. 6.

facts.text: High Court accepted respondents' contention that s.4(1) notification of 1949 was exhausted by previous s.6 notifications and quashed the August 12, 1960 s.6 notification.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has accepted the contention of the respondents and has held that a notification under s. 4(1) can only be followed by one notification under S. 6 ... In consequence the petition was allowed and the notification dated August 12, 1960 quashed.

facts.text: Appellant applied to High Court for certificate, which was granted.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then applied to the High Court for a certificate which was granted and that is how the matter has come up before us.

facts.text: It is not in dispute that a number of s.6 notifications were issued with respect to village Chhawani.

anchor.surface_text: and it is not in dispute that a number of such notifications under S. 6 were issued with respect to village Chhawani

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that only one declaration under s.6 per notification under s.4(1).

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the High Court was right in holding that there can be no successive notifications under S. 6 with respect to land in a locality specified in one notification under S. 4(1).

facts.text: Appeal dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: I would for these reasons dismiss the appeal with costs.

facts.text: The 1949 s.4(1) notification did not contain any direction relevant to s.17(4).

anchor.surface_text: The present is not a case of this kind, for the notification under S. 4(1) in this case issued in May 1949 did not contain any direction relevant to S. 17(4).

facts.text: The 1960 s.6 declaration contains a direction under s.17(4).

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the declaration under S. 6 dated August 12, 1960 contains a direction under s. 17(4),

facts.text: Writ petition also raised ground that the s.6 notification was vague.

anchor.surface_text: The petition had also raised a ground that the notification under S. 6 was vague.

The question that has arisen is whether a number of declarations under S. 6 of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894 can be issued successively in respect of different pieces of lands included within the locality specified in a numberification issued under S. 4 of the Act.

issues.text: whether a number of declarations under S. 6 of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894 can be issued successively in respect of different pieces of lands included within the locality specified in a notification issued under S. 4 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The question that has arisen is whether a number of declarations under S. 6 of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894 can be issued successively in respect of different pieces of lands included within the locality specified in a numberification issued under S. 4 of the Act.

issues.text: whether it is open to the appropriate government to issue successive notifications under s. 6 of the Land Acquisition Act, No. 1 of 1894, with respect to land comprised within one notification under s. 4(1) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: Wanchoo, J.-The only question raised in this appeal on a certificate granted by the Madhya Pradesh High Court is whether it is open to the appropriate government to issue successive numberifications under s. 6 of the Land Acquisition Act, No. 1 of 1894,  hereinafter referred to as the Act  with respect to land companyprised within one numberification under s. 4 1  of the Act.

arguments.claim: A notification under s.4(1) can only be followed by one notification under s.6 and there can be no successive notifications under s.6 with respect to lands comprised in one notification under s.4(1)

anchor.surface_text: In substance the contention of the respondents in their petition was that a notification under s. 4(1) could be followed only by one notification under s. 6 and that there could be no successive notifications under s. 6 with respect to lands comprised in one notification under s. 4(1).

anchor.surface_text: My learned brother has said that ss. 4, 5A and 6 of the Act have to be read together and so read, the conclusion is clear that the Act contemplates only a single declaration under s. 6 in respect of a notification under s. 4.

Balancing interests: interpret to protect owner from prejudice of delay/price rise while govt can issue fresh s.4 if needed

anchor.surface_text: Secondly, in interpreting these provisions the court must keep in view on the one hand the public interest which compels such acquisition and on the other the interest of the person who is being deprived of his land without his consent.

arguments.claim: s.17(4) does not permit successive s.6 generally; at most two in special urgency cases but govt can issue separate s.4

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the declaration under S. 6 dated August 12, 1960 contains a direction under s. 17(4), ... Section 17(1) gives power to government in cases of urgency to direct that the Collector should take possession of-the land before the award is made

arguments.qualifiers: not final opinion on two s.6

arguments.claim: s.48 withdrawal not only way to end s.4; power to rescind under General Clauses Act s.21

anchor.surface_text: The next contention was that s. 48 which gives the Government power of withdrawal from acquisition before taking possession implies that a notification under s. 4 remains in force ... under S. 21 of the General Clauses Act, No. 10 of 1897,

arguments.claim: ss.49(2),(3) special case requiring no fresh s.6 for severed land; implies no general successive s.6

holdings.text: There can be no successive notifications under S. 6 with respect to land in a locality specified in one notification under S. 4(1). The notification under S. 4(1) exhausts itself after one notification under S. 6.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the High Court was right in holding that there can be no successive notifications under S. 6 with respect to land in a locality specified in one notification under S. 4(1).

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction of ss. 4, 5A, 6 shows integral process: s.4(1) specifies locality, s.5A single hearing/report, s.6 single declaration; strict construction of expropriatory statute; balances public interest and owner prejudice from delay.

holdings.text: The Act contemplates only a single declaration under s. 6 in respect of a notification under s. 4.

anchor.surface_text: My learned brother has said that ss. 4, 5A and 6 of the Act have to be read together and so read, the conclusion is clear that the Act contemplates only a single declaration under s. 6

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreement with Wanchoo J.'s reasoning on integrated scheme of ss. 4, 5A, 6.

holdings.text: Provisions of s.17(4) do not lead to conclusion that s.6 contemplates successive notifications following one s.4(1); at most two in urgency cases but government can issue separate s.4(1).

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the declaration under S. 6 dated August 12, 1960 contains a direction under s. 17(4), ... Section 17(1) gives power to government in cases of urgency to direct that the Collector should take possession of-the land before the award is made

holdings.reasoning_summary: Special urgency provision does not alter general scheme; no direction in 1949 s.4(1); separate s.4(1) possible.

holdings.text: s.48 withdrawal power does not imply s.4(1) remains in force permitting successive s.6; can rescind under General Clauses Act s.21.

anchor.surface_text: The next contention was that s. 48 which gives the Government power of withdrawal from acquisition before taking possession implies that a notification under s. 4 remains in force ... under S. 21 of the General Clauses Act, No. 10 of 1897,

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.48 special for post-s.9 stage; rescission power exists separately; s.4(1) exhausted by s.6.

holdings.text: ss.49(2) and (3) provide special case for severed land without fresh s.6; do not support general successive s.6 declarations.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Special statutory provision implies no general power; requires explicit authorization for multiples.

holdings.text: Appeal dismissed; 1960 s.6 notification quashed as following exhausted 1949 s.4(1).

anchor.surface_text: I would for these reasons dismiss the appeal with costs.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of holding h1 to facts.

precedents.citation: Babu Barkya Thakur v. The State of Bombay, 1 1961 1 S.C.R. 128

anchor.surface_text: As was. observed by this Court in Babu Barkya Thakur v. The State of Bombay, 1 1961 1 S.C.R. 128 . It seems to us clear that when such a report is received from the Collector by the government it must give a decision on all the objections at one stage and decide once for all what particular land out of the locality numberified under S. 4 1  it wishes to acquire, It has to be satisfied under s. 6 after companysidering the report made under S. 5-A that a particular land is needed for a public purpose or for a companypany and it then makes a declaration to that effect under s. 6.
